review.title: On the cost-complexity of multi-context systems
review.abstract: Multi-context systems provide a powerful framework for modelling information-aggregation systems featuring heterogeneous reasoning components. Their execution can, however, incur non-negligible cost. Here, we focus on cost-complexity of such systems. To that end, we introduce cost-aware multi-context systems, an extension of non-monotonic multi-context systems framework taking into account costs incurred by execution of semantic operators of the individual contexts. We formulate the notion of cost-complexity for consistency and reasoning problems in MCSs. Subsequently, we provide a series of results related to gradually more and more constrained classes of MCSs and finally introduce an incremental cost-reducing algorithm solving the reasoning problem for definite MCSs.

metadata.title: On the cost-complexity of multi-context systems

sections.text: ar Xiv: 140 5.72 95v1 [cs.AI] 2Multi-context systems provide a powerful framework for modelling information aggregation systems with heterogeneous argumentation components, but their execution cannot incur negligible costs. In this context, we focus on the cost complexity of such systems. To this end, we introduce cost-conscious multi-context systems, an extension of the non-monotonous multi-context system, taking into account the costs of executing semantic operators of individual contexts. We formulate the concept of cost complexity for consistency and reasoning problems in MCSs. We then provide a set of results that relate to gradually more and more limited classes of MCSs, and finally, we introduce a step-by-step, cost-effective algorithm that solves the argument problem for defined MCSs.

sections.heading: 4 Definite cost-aware MCS
sections.text: The characteristics of the complexity of reasoning with general cost-conscious multi-context systems as introduced in the previous section are rather pessimistic. However, even valiant reasoning leads to a general cost complexity that is exponential in the size of the information flow structure of the system. For practical reasons, this can become prohibitive as the size of the system is scalable. However, often, information flows of the implemented systems are more simply structured, both in terms of the individual context and the underlying information flow. definite multi-context systems, an adaptation of the notion of reducible MCSs (Brewka & Eiter, 2007), provide a suitable model for such contexts. sections.heading: 6 Incremental reasoning in definite MCS
sections.text: The discourses in previous sections followed the structure of the standard results from logic programming, which is reflected in multi-context systems. In general, the cost-complexity of the results depends on the known results of the computational time-complexity of the computation of such programs. In this section, we build on the concepts presented above and present an incremental approach to the computation of cost-conscious multi-context systems, which specifically focuses on reducing the cost-complexity of such computations. By using the structure of a given MCS in relation to a given query, the actual cost-complexity of solving the argumentation problem can often be improved. Before introducing an actual algorithm that reduces the number of context evaluations, let us first introduce an idea of a fragmentation context, which is complementary to context support (definition 19), but instead of taking into account the context and rules that are necessary for a context.

sections.heading: 7 Discussion and final remarks
sections.text: The motivating premise underlying the presented work is that MCSs are a suitable model for designing, implementing and analyzing knowledge-intensive systems with heterogeneous components used. Here, we expand the generic model of multi-context systems with an idea of costs aimed at executing semantic operators of individual contexts. The idea is to facilitate the scalability of the system in terms of costs incurred, whether by computation costs, bandwidth or even financial expenditure. Our focus on cost-complexity rather than the computation-complexity of algorithms also represents a novel view of the design and use of information aggregation and argumentation systems. We conducted a series of worst-case complexity outcomes for general, defined and layered MCSs. Some of these outcomes could be further improved by taking inspiration from e.g. Bairaket al., 2010, where the authors may fragmented their MCSs results into their composition.
